content.description: The right arete of the area. Broken rock arete climbing with a nice bulge up top that protects well. There is some sketchy looking rock, but we banged away at it all and took off all the obviously loose stuff. It protects well and is relatively easy climbing, but be careful on the rock.
content.protection: Single rack, perhaps doubles of medium cams if you like to place a lot of gear.
content.location: The arete at the right side of this wall.

content.description: Far left of the wall. Start on easy ground to clip the lower bolt, move above it to access nice horizontal crack to broken vertical crack, to good face climbing to a large horizontal crack and ledge before the final arete/bulge/crack to the anchors. Same anchors as for the other two climbs.
content.protection: Single bolt that is easily clipped, some small-medium nuts and small-medium cams.

content.description: Middle of the wall, nice face climbing to broken vertical crack. The best rock and funnest moves of the wall. Straight up to the anchors.

This is the first east-facing wall on your right as you're entering the corridor to get into the Glade Wall area. It's directly left from the Towers area and just after the "doggie tunnel" (those of you with dogs will know what that is!). We've always wondered about these climbs and hadn't developed them initially because they were less compelling than the others in this region.
